this video is a complete mess, don't believe it :D this only shows 1 way (and also using wrong terms, like saying oxidation=fermentation is wrong), also how the water temperature should be for brewing, depends on tea type, and the customer's taste, conditions, etc... and there is like 20 different statement in the video that is wrong, I'm just lazy to comment on all of them :D
this video only shows how is this particular oolong tea is made in this particular factory (without fermentation), picking, withering, shaking, oxidising, fixing, rolling, drying, etc. there is a bunch other steps that can be involved, roasting, fermenting, aging, filtering, cleaning out of twigs (if machine picked for example), or steaming (fixing japanese green tea) and who knows what.. secret steps that can be a family secret that is inherited by generation to generation
its as complicated as wine, you can't just call a video "How is it made: wine" then just show a video of one producer who makes one pinot noir and pretend all wine is made the same way.

This video makes a huge but weirdly common mistake. Fermentation is not the same as oxidation. It's not that anywhere else and it's not that in tea. Oxidation has to do with reacting to air (You can also see this in e.g. bruised fruit). Fermentation has to do with microbes. Black tea is not fermented. It is only oxidised. Oolong is also not fermented. Fermented tea does also exist and it forms its own category. Pu erh is an example of fermented tea.
